results.title: Journey (Sen)
results.brief_description: A young boy leaves his isolated home town hitching across a forever changing landscape. His travels cause him to relive fragments of the life left behind as he struggles to find rest in a journey that may never end. An award winning short from Indigenous filmmaker Ivan Sen whose other films include Tears, Wind and Dust.

results.title: Icon
results.brief_description: A comedy about the gender of god and the real wishes of the Virgin Mary. Hugely successful, this one minute short has screened at festivals throughout Australia and Europe, and at the United Women’s Conference in Beijing.

results.title: Has beans
results.creator_credit: Andrew Tamandl, AFTRS and Miriam Stein
results.brief_description: The world is full of war and where can we hope to escape it? Home? - Certainly not by a stretch of this little computer animation. A lone kidney bean is being given the rough treatment by two much larger, bullying lima beans. In a number of fancy manoeuvres the kidney bean tricks the bullying two into believing they’ve killed him. When the kidney bean reaches his kin a battle of revenge is planned. The plan is foiled once ensconced in battle by the true ruler - he/she who cooks beans in the kitchen. The battle scenes are stylistically similar to and remniscent of the battle scenes in the paintings of Australian artist, John Bracks, where he used pencils and decks of cards symbolically and as structural elements to recreate battle scenes. No dialogue, sound effects only.

results.title: Harry's War ( Crossing Tracks )
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, Jill Bilcock and John Foss
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Love Della
results.brief_description: This is a 50’s home movie style portrait of a fictional 19 year old, undiscovered jazz starlet, called Della Ray ( Kate Cebrano).Though recently shot, the film masquerades convincingly as found footage of a 50’s jazz club and its inhabitants. It begins with a roller coaster jam session featuring unknown local musicians of 1958, and ends with an impromptu number by the delightful Delia herself, who “died” in the tradition of the jazz greats, shortly after the footage was shot. Features excellent original 50’s jazz numbers.

results.title: Pentuphouse
results.brief_description: An aging jazz singer (played with poignant resolve by Gillian Jones) must contend with her highly strung, drug using boyfriend. Director Cate Shortland traces with assured confidence the complex and delicate nuances of aging and compromise within a self destructive relationship.
results.description: An aging jazz singer (played with poignant resolve by Gillian Jones) must contend with her highly strung, drug using boyfriend. results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 - Red
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red was broadcast as the first of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason), The Visitor (Andrew Till) and Third Eye (Ollie Olsen).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon VI: VAT
results.brief_description:
After the success of Spectrum, the Cyberthon artists were invited by Telstra to create a submission for an exhibition called The Edge, to be displayed at the Telstra Corporate Center on Exhibition Street. This demo was presented to Telstra at an annual meeting held at Dallas Brooks Hall.

The demo shows a CGI artists impression of the proposed ‘The Edge exhibition’ space as well as a simulation of the media submission process via the interactive Cyberthon VAT (V=Video, A=Audio, T=Text) porthole created using Deluxe Paint, with presentation edited in Scala on an Amiga 2000.

Animation loops that appear in simulated submission section were created by Ian Haig, Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent and Dale Nason), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton & Attillio Gangemi), Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Julian Wong, Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, and Force Fed (Stuart McCormick). Video camera footage was shot by Dale Nason from the back of a Chris Wrights moving van. 35mm still photographs were taken by Tao Wiess. Audio track was mixed by DJ Visitor (Andrew Till).

This work is part of the Cyberthon Archive, generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
